awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Infrared-driven organic light-emitting diode (OLED) projection display
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide an innovative, cost-effective, highly-flexible, extremely-large display screen technology with excellent display image qualities. The proposed innovative organic light emitting diode (OLED) display technology may fulfill the societal need for extremely-large and high-quality display screens for use in venues such as schools, churches, and theaters. Furthermore, the novel display approach is environmentally-friendly, only requiring a simple solution-based inkjet printing processes instead of environmentally disruptive and damaging semiconductor manufacturing processes.

This I-Corps project aims to evaluate the commercial potential of a new cost-effective, highly-flexible, extremely-large display screen technology and to accelerate the translation of this technology into emerging products. Direct conversations with prospective customers will allow for greater understanding of customer segments and further value proposition refinement. Participation will also help the I-Corps team clarify business and technology directions such as refining the product development process to target and identify specific market needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Despite unsatisfactory image quality and the subsequent need for a darkened room, conventional projection displays are still used extensively in school classrooms and churches, because there is currently no alternative technology enabling equivalently large display screens (100 ~ 500 inches) that would remedy these drawbacks. The goal of this I-Corps Program project was to investigate the commercialization potential of a new OLED-based self-emitting projection screen technology that can realize extremely-large display screens and at the same time excellent display image quality like high-end organic light-emitting diode (OLED) TVs.

Our team conducted more than 150 interviews with potential customers and stakeholders in the projection display sectors. Direct conversations with prospective customers allowed for a greater understanding of our customer sub-segmentation and further narrowing of our value proposition. Participation in the I-Corps cohort also helped significantly the I-Corp team clarify the direction the business and technology can take going forward such as refining the product development process to target and meet identified specific market needs.

Before we attended this I-Corps program, we simply thought that our infrared-stimulated OLED projection display would definitely replace all the projectors around the world. As soon as we started engaging with our potential customers, however, we recognized things are not that simple and easy. Unlike our expectation, a lot of prospective customer segments we initially thought as our potential customers no longer need our solution able to realize large projection screens with excellent display image qualities. After an incredibly large amount of interviews with our potential customers in significant guidance and supports from the I-Corps teaching team, we finally found the very specific customer segment that really need our new projection display solutions.

Two Ph.D. students had participated in the NSF I-Corps program as an entrepreneurial lead and a co-entrepreneurial lead. During the I-Corps program participation, they can have a significant opportunity to gain an understanding of the basic principles of entrepreneurship and crafting a refined value proposition for our potential products.
